723981f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - Washington Square West
723981f-a.text:
Washington Square, showing arch

Date:  About 1920

Photographer:  Jessie Tarbox Beals
723981f-a.folder: Washington Square & Washington Square West, Manhattan, NY

723984f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - Washington Square West
723984f-a.text:
Washington Arch, Washington Square, seen from the north so as to show the Judson Memorial Baptist Church (1892) framed in the archway, and the fountain in the center of the park. The church stands on the S.W. corner of Thompson Street and Washington
Square South (4th Street).
This arch was built around 1890; the wooden one designed by Stanford White for the Centenary of President Washington's inauguration, in 1889, was so well liked that it was decided to erect a permanent
arch of stone, which White also designed.
About 1925.
Ewing Galloway.
723984f-a.folder: Washington Square & Washington Square West, Manhattan, NY

724035f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 4th Street (West)
724035f-a.folder: Washington Square North & 4th Street (West), Manhattan, NY

724046f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square West - 4th Street
724046f-a.text:
Washiwgtow Square West, from 4th Street to Washingtow Place, showing the twin 7-story builsings of the Holley Hotel ia the center of the block. This is one of the three original Knott hotels, and was wamed after Alexander J. Holley, of whom a bust has stood in
Washington Square since 1890.
The 3-story builsing on the corner of Washington Place, a part of the hotel, will be torn aown in 1930 ans replaces by the 16-story Holley Chambers. The three houses iw the southern half of the block will also be replaced by a tall apartment buileing.
December 28, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
Neg w tiSo
724046f-a.folder: Washington Square West & 4th Street, Manhattan, NY

723989f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - Washington Square West
723989f-b.text:
Washington Square, seen from a roof at Sixth Avenue near 4th Street. The principal New York University building is on Washington Square East from Washington to Waverly Flaces. On the N.E. corner of Waverly and University Places a tall apartment building is going to be erected in 1929. The tall building north of the scuare is the new One Fifth Avenue. To the right may be seen the new apartment building at 32 Washington Square West, recently erected on the site of the old Hicks-Lorc house. Behind it, on the horison, the tower of the Consolidated Gas building, Irving Place
and 14th Street, is nearing completion.
Nearer in the foreground are the roofs of the Holley Hotel, 35-6 Washington Square West, and the old houses 37-39, which are soow to be replaced by an apartment building. The spires in the immediate foreground beloag to the Washington Sduare Methodist Episcopal Church at 135 West Fourth Street. Down in the park, to the right of the fountain, and nearer, may be seen the newly
rebuilt comfort station.
April 3, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
Sixth Avenue,West side,at West 4th Street,north west from Third Street,showing the Excelsior Accordion Manafacturing Company's
building.
March 15th,1932.
P.L.Sperr,
No reproductions.

723998f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 4th Street (West)
723998f-a.text:
Washington Square North, east from about 8 Washington Square. These old reSidences contrast with the receatly erectes 21-story apartment building on the N.E. corner of Waverly Place and University Place, built in 1929. In the right foregrouns is shown part of Washingtow Arch, giving a very good profile view
of Washington.
About 1931.
Ewing Galloway.

710929f-a.text:
West 4th Street, south side, west from and including MacDougal Street, to Sixth Ave.
May 24, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

710904f-a.text:
146 West 4th Street, south side, between Macdougal Street and Sixth Avenue, occupied by a typical Greenwich Village restaurant.
May 24, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

723987f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square West - 4th Street
723987f-a.text:
Washington Square West, from 4th Street to Waverly Place, inclusive, showing the old Hotel Holley buildings in the middle of the southern block, with a new building on either side, and the new
apartment hotels in the northern block.
At 103 Waverly Place, adjoining the Earle Annex on the N.W. corner,
is the Hotel Earle, built around 1905.
February 24, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
723987f-a.folder: Washington Square West & 4th Street, Manhattan, NY

724005f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 4th Street (West)
724005f-a.text:
20-14 and 13-l Washington Square North, seen from a tall building on Washington Square West, showing the N.E. corner of the Square and the East Side skyline. Part of the New York University building on the S.E. corner of Waverly Place is visible beside the new 1 University Place apartment house ow the N.E. corner. To the left of One Fifth Avenue is the Hotel Brevoort at the N.E. corner of Fifth Avenue and 8th Street, and behind the N.W. shoulder of One Fifth Avenue is the tower of the Consolidated Gas Building
on Fourteenth Street.
August, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
724005f-a.folder: Washington Square North & 4th Street (West), Manhattan, NY

724028f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square Park - [Washington Square (South).]
724028f-a.text:
Washington Square Park,on the Northern side as seen from #7I
Washington Square South.
This is a good view of the Northern part of the Park,with Washington Arch in the center foreground. In the left background may be seen the old Jefferson Market Clock Tower;a survival from
the 1870s at Sixth Avenue and 10th Street.
July 1935.
P.L.Sperr.
No Reproductions.

723978f-b.text:
Washington Square:  The northeasterly corner of same, view-ing northward from a point on it's easterly boundary, Wash-ington Square East, at Washington Place.  In the left back-ground is the towering apartment house, No.1 Fifth Avenue.

October 14, 1939
